awd_titl_txt: SemiSynBio-II: DNA-Based Memory for High-Density Information Storage and Molecular Cryptography with Fast Readout Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
The need for secured computer and internet storage has seen a rapid increase over time. To address this challenge, this project will develop a DNA nanotechnology-based cryptographic protocol for writing and reading digital data. It will be developed to enable both high-capacity and highly-secured information storage and high-speed information retrieval. DNA nanotechnology will be utilized to encrypt information in molecular patterns formed upon DNA folding, which is uniquely determined by a set of DNA information strands and a special folding route of DNA strands that function as the encryption keys. The programmability of DNA nanostructures creates a vast design space for the encryption keys, making it practically impossible to intercept and break the encryption. The molecular patterns on DNA nanostructures will be characterized by a super-resolution imaging method and a low-noise nanopore device. These methods can enable fast readout speed at 1 megahertz with a high spatial resolution of smaller than 10 nanometers. If successful, this DNA-based storage has a potential to be implemented on a portable platform, thus strongly supporting the development of next-generation DNA-based memories with significantly improved security and storage density at a low cost. Consequently, the secured DNA-based storage will benefit the U.S. economy and society. This research involves several disciplines including nanofabrication, materials science, biochemistry, electronics, photonics, and data science. The project will engage underrepresented groups in the research and positively impact STEM education.

DNA has emerged as a promising candidate to store information that can rival semiconductor memory, due to its high stability, high information density, and accompanying readout technologies. However, the potential of DNA as a material for highly-secured information storage has not been fully exploited. Additionally, the readout of conventional DNA-based memories has been limited by DNA sequencing, which requires special instruments and personnel training. This research is to fill the knowledge gap by creating a significantly improved and high-security DNA-based molecular cryptography and establishing a high-speed, high-resolution, and potentially portable readout platform for DNA memory. The research team will embed encrypted information in three-dimensional DNA origami nanostructures in the form of nanoscopic patterns. A pool of DNA scaffold strands decorated with specific information strands (i-strands) of different sequences, lengths, and binding positions will be designed on the basis of a chosen DNA folding scheme out of many possibilities, which will be used later in decryption of the pattern of i-strands. The high spatial resolution of DNA-PAINT (DNA-based point accumulation for imaging in nanoscopic topography) (<20 nm) and sapphire-supported nanopore sensors (<10 nm) will support high-density information decryption of intricate single-molecule patterns on the DNA origami, while enabling a fast readout speed of up to 1 MHz. The fast readout methods will employ deep-learning classification techniques for automated decryption and improved accuracy. The encryption scheme, single-molecule characterization methods, nanopore sensor designs, and data analysis algorithms will be synergistically improved in this project to enable robust and effective information storage and transmission.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
DNA molecules have been the fundamental information-storage molecules that drove the evolution of life for billions of years. Recently, DNA emerges as a promising candidate to store artificial information that can rival semiconductor memory, due to their high stability, high information density, and the accompanying readout technologies. However, the potential of DNA as a material has not been fully exploited for information storage. Additionally, the readout of conventional DNA based memories has been seriously limited by expensive DNA sequencing. This project aims to develop a high-information-density and hard-to-breach molecular cryptography that exploits a large number of possible folding patterns of a long single-stranded DNA (referred to as a scaffold strand in DNA origami technique).

Specifically, exquisite positional control of DNA origami nanotechnology is used to encrypt information in the form of spot patterns for assembling prescribed shapes and patterns. The information is accordingly decrypted by folding the DNA origami with the staple strands to reveal the pattern of information-coding strands. The vast design space of the staple strand sets (sequences, length, and binding location on the scaffold strand) makes it extremely difficult or impossible to intercept and break the encryption.

Equally importantly to encryption, state-of-the-art characterization methods in DNA-PAINT (DNA-based point accumulation for imaging in nanoscale topography) and sapphire based nanopores have been developed for high-speed readout. DNA-PAINT enables super-resolution imaging of DNA origami structures below the diffraction limit, and sapphire based nanopores allows readout of the nanoscopic patterns on DNA origami nanotubes with improved signal-to-noise ratio a high recording speed.

Scalable manufacturing strategies are developed to reproducibly create small and thin dielectric membranes on sapphire via anisotropic wet etching of sapphire. Specifically, two designs were successfully demonstrated to produce small (micrometer-sized) membranes over 2-inch wafers, using triangular and hexagonal shaped etching window designs, respectively. This strategy allows to achieve a very small chip capacitance of smaller than 2 pico Farad, which is hundred times better than that from a conventional silicon chip. Based on these efforts, four-helix bundle (4HB) DNA origami structures have been designed to carry information in DNA way-junctions to achieve both design flexibility and data security, and sapphire-supported, low-noise nanopores have been used for high-speed (250 kHz) readout with a high signal-to-noise ratio. Assisted by decision-tree supervised learning, the messages are correctly classified with a high accuracy (>90%), proving the feasibility of encoding letters and messages for information retrieval.

In parallel, the team developed an encryption-decryption pipeline where binary data is embedded into 2D and 3D DNA origami structures and decoded using DNA-PAINT (a form of super-resolution microscopy) and clustering algorithms. This method achieved encryption key sizes of up to 700 bits which is substantially exceeding conventional digital encryption protocols and demonstrated a high (~89%) decryption accuracy. Bit redundancy was incorporated to improve reliability even when DNA structures showed slight variations.

Together, these innovations lay the groundwork for DNA-based data storage systems that are secure, high-capacity, and free from the constraints of DNA sequencing. Potential applications include long-term archival storage, secure communication, biomedical data protection, and molecular-scale sensing technologies.

This multidisciplinary project contributed meaningfully to STEM education and workforce development. Ph.D. students, master’s students, and  undergraduate students received trainings across different disciplines such as DNA nanotechnology, chip fabrication, microfluidics, optics, and machine learning. The hands-on experience fostered skills at the intersection of biology, engineering, and data science.

Dissemination of results included peer-reviewed publications and preprints, as well as presentations at international conferences. This work not only advances scientific understanding of molecular information systems but also strengthens the pipeline for training future leaders in nanotechnology, bioengineering, and secure data technologies.

 


Last Modified: 03/28/2025
Modified by: Chao Wang
